description: A tourist bus has been idling for nearly an hour outside, illegally double parked on Atlantic Ave. This is very unusual for our neighborhood. It's also loud and polluting our air. Please have a police officer have them tell to relocate.

Resident parking:

Due to the expanding neighborhood & the increase of cars & visitors (with out of state plates).   I am hopeful that the powers that be are working on a 7 days of week resident parking in all South Boston neighborhoods.  I moved to South Boston when I was 23 years old because I could afford it and I embraced the friendliness of this last neighborhood in the greater metro area.  23 years later I am still here and value what is left of this neighborhood & respect my community.  But, when I have to drive around for 20-30 minutes looking for a legal spot it infuriates me when I pass all the out of state plates taking up the much coveted parking spaces especially since I pay taxes here.
Please consider the 7 days a week rule;  most if not all the neighborhoods in Boston already enforce this.  
Your humble neighbor,
Kelley Bowker

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Department did not issue a street opening permit to Spectra for the pipeline work. The Federal Government issued the permit which allows Spectra to work Monday through Saturday 7am to 7pm. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) contacted Spectra and asked them why they were working beyond the Federally permitted hours .  They stated they had to do work on their substation on Grove St which is their private property.  They also stated that they tried to mitigate the noise through the use of sound blankets. They City informed Spectra going forward that if they were going to work on their private property they would notify the CIU 48 hours in advance. In addition, the City may have the noise levels measured to insure the decibel levels do not go above the City ordinance.  They agreed to those terms. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.

status_notes: Case Resolved. Dear Constituent,. The Boston Public Works Department did not issue a street opening permit to Spectra for the pipeline work. The Federal Government issued the permit which allows Spectra to work Monday through Saturday 7am to 7pm. The Boston Public Works Construction Inspection Unit (CIU) contacted Spectra and asked them why they were working Saturday night past 7pm and on Sunday.  They stated they had to do work on their substation on Grove St which is their private property.  They also stated that they tried to mitigate the noise through the use of sound blankets. They City informed Spectra going forward that if they were going to work on their private property they would notify the CIU 48 hours in advance. In addition, the City may have the noise levels measured to insure the decibel levels do not go above the City ordinance.  They agreed to those terms. For any questions or concerns, please contact the number listed below. Sincerely,. . Mark Cardarelli. Supervisor of Utility Coordination and Compliance. Boston Public Works Department. 617-635-4951.
description: Once again @spectraEnergy is working long after their stop time of 7:00 PM.  They are running some kind of very loud machinery, disturbing the whole area. This after working all day Sunday and many other Sundays. This is ridiculous. #StopSpectra.
